summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to the Metropolitan Detention Center Legal Department providing passwords for discovery materials related to the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The document is a procedural communication regarding evidence access in the criminal prosecution.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) for which discovery materials are being provided; the passwords are for accessing evidence related to her prosecution.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The signatory of the letter, representing the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, transmitting the passwords for discovery materials.

connections.description: Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is part of the prosecution team handling the criminal case against Maxwell, as indicated by the case reference and the provision of discovery materials.

events.title: Transmission of Discovery Passwords
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends passwords for a hard drive and CD containing discovery materials related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case to the Metropolitan Detention Center Legal Department.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
Metropolitan Detention Center, 80 29th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11232
keyFacts: The document is a formal communication from the U.S. Attorney's Office providing access credentials for discovery materials in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell.
The case is identified as United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), indicating an ongoing federal prosecution.
Discovery materials are stored on both a hard drive and a CD, each with its own password, suggesting a substantial volume of evidence.
The correspondence is addressed to the legal department of the Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell was likely held at the time.
Audrey Strauss was serving as Acting United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York as of November 2020.
